awd_titl_txt: Exploring the Origin of Heavy Elements: Nuclear Input for P-Process Nucleosynthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Nuclear astrophysics is the study of how elements are created in various stellar environments and how such environments evolve. For example, stellar burning is responsible for the production of elements up to iron, and neutron capture processes create most of the heavy elements. However, the origin of heavy, proton-rich nuclei above iron is one of the greatest puzzles of stellar nucleosynthesis. The most likely scenario for creating these isotopes is the p-process: a complex network of photodisintegration reactions and their inverse (proton-, alpha- and neutron-capture) that occur during the explosion of a supernova. A vast network of 20,000 nuclear reactions for the p-process relies on models to provide input of nuclear properties and reaction rates for all the nuclei involved in the network. The goal of this project is to identify the reactions that are key for the p-process and to measure them directly, so as to minimize the uncertainty for those rates and provide constraints for the model predictions. 

This project will contribute to understanding of the stellar p-process by measuring cross sections for proton and alpha capture reactions of relevance for Pd-102, Cd-108, Cd-110, Te-120 and Te-122. Those reactions have not been measured before, and have been identified as key for the p-process by two independent sensitivity studies. Studies have shown that the variations of those rates within the current model uncertainties have a significant impact on the production of the p-nuclei. The project will utilize a newly purchased detector (HECTOR) to employ the γ-summing technique. The impact of the measured reaction rates on the final abundances of the p-nuclei will be verified using network calculations whose results will be compared with the solar abundances. Additionally, the measured cross sections will be compared with model predictions and will be used to identify the model inputs that best reproduce the data.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project was to constrain the proton and alpha capture reactions around mass A=100 to better understand the nucleosynthesis of the proton-rich isotopes of elements in this mass region. These nuclei are formed during explosive events such as type II supernovae in a violent process of photodisintegration of preexisting s-process seeds. The process, called the gamma-process, is responsible for the formation of the p-nuclei, proton-rich isotopes of nuclei between selenium and mercury that cannot be produced by the neutron capture of the s- and r-processes.

The gamma-process is a complex network of (g,n), (g,p) and (g,a) reactions that begin at stable s-process isotopes and as the shockwave moves through the layers of the supernova, the reactions shift the abundances towards the exotic proton-rich isotopes which then beta-decay to stability once the shockwave has passed. The photodisintegration chain starts with the (g,n) reactions that push the abundance along the isotopic lines until a branching point is reached. At the branching point nuclei, the (g,p) or (g,a) reactions become dominant shifting the flow towards lighter nuclei. The competition between the photodisintegration reactions is responsible for the final abundances of the p-nuclei and variations in the flow can greatly modify the final p-nuclei production.

In this work, the focus was on Pd and Cd isotopes in search for branching points in this mass region. The temperatures at which these nuclei become branching points were unknown, due to large uncertainties in the reaction rates. With our work, we provided a better constraint to those rates and determined the branching temperature with a very high accuracy.

Additionally, through systematic measurements of the capture reactions across the chains of isotopes, we provided a set of inputs for the Hauser-Feshbach models describing the reaction rates in A=100 mass region. This allows for an improved modeling of the gamma-process and reduces the uncertainties in the model predictions that stem from the nuclear physics input. This allows for a more precise modeling of the p-process nucleosynthesis and better understanding of the astrophysical environment where the p-process is occurring.

The project also served as a training opportunity for the next generation of scientists in nuclear physics. Several graduate and undergraduate students were involved in all aspects of this project. They planned and executed the experiments, analyzed the data and disseminated the results to the community ? through publications as well as conference presentations.

 


Last Modified: 10/12/2022
Modified by: Anna Simon-Robertson
